member.summary: Wraps a multidimensional array to look like a linear list.
member.remarks: In the MSDN documentation, the Array class claims to implement IList. In fact, this interface is only supported for one-dimensional arrays. ArrayAsList provides this missing functionality for multidimensional arrays.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.CursorArray`1
member.summary: A multidimensional array of objects which share a single storage block.

remarks.para: A CursorArray is meant to behave like an ordinary Array, while being more memory-efficient. Instead of storing multiple instances of the same object type, it uses a single instance as a cursor over a block of data. The cursor acts like a pointer which is targeted at the desired part of the array (via its Start property).

The CursorArray object does not hold a pointer to the actual source data. It is agnostic about the actual type and layout of the data that the cursor is walking over, providing a large degree of flexibility in the implementation of the cursor.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.CursorArray`1.MoveTo(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Position the cursor at a multidimensional index.

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.CursorArray`1.Item(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Retrieve an object by multidimensional index.
member.remarks: The result is a volatile cursor object, which becomes invalid on the next indexer call. This can be a source of bugs, e.g. f(a[i],a[j]) will not work. If you want to save a result across calls, you must make a ReferenceClone, as in: f(a[i].ReferenceClone(), a[j]).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.CursorArray`1.MoveTo(System.Int32)
member.summary: Position the cursor at a linear index.

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.CursorArray`1.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieve an object by linear index.

remarks.para: If the array is multidimensional, this will index the elements sequentially in row-major order, i.e. the rightmost dimension varies fastest.

The result is a volatile cursor object, which becomes invalid on the next indexer call. This can be a source of bugs, e.g. f(a[i],a[j]) will not work. If you want to save a result across calls, you must make a ReferenceClone, as in: f(a[i].ReferenceClone(), a[j]).

member.summary: The total number of structures across all dimensions

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.FileArray`1
member.summary: An IArray where each element is stored as a disk file.
member.typeparam: The element type

remarks.para: The elements (whose values do not equal default(T)) are stored as individual files in a temp folder. Elements equal to default(T) are not stored. A FileArray may contain FileArrays as elements: these are called child FileArrays. Child FileArrays must be created using the special constructor. When a FileArray (that is not a child) is Disposed or garbage collected, the folder is deleted. A child FileArray is deleted only when its parent is deleted. Thus if the program exits normally, all temp folders should be deleted. However, if the program halts with an exception, temp folders will not be deleted and must be cleaned up manually.

Be careful when modifying elements of the FileArray in place. If fa is a FileArray, then the syntax fa[i][j] = 0; or fa[i].property = 0; will not have any effect. This happens because fa[i] reads the element from disk but does not write it back again. You must explicitly read the element, modify it, then write it back like so: T item = fa[i]; item.property=0; fa[i] = item;

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.ParallelCursorArray`2
member.summary: A multidimensional array of objects where each field is in a CursorArray.
member.typeparam: A cursor-based array type, such as CursorArray or ParallelCursorArray.

remarks.para: A ParallelCursorArray is meant to behave like an ordinary Array, while being more memory-efficient. It uses a cursor similar to a CursorArray. However, the storage layout is different. Each field of the cursor is stored in a separate ICursorArray, with its own inner cursor. By advancing these inner cursors, the outer cursor is automatically updated. Thus does not need to implement ICursor. For example, might be Array<ICursor>, holding an array of inner cursors.
There must be at least one member array, and all member arrays must have the same dimensions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Collections.ParallelCursorArray`2.#ctor(`0,System.Collections.Generic.IList{`1})
member.summary: Create a new ParallelCursorArray.
member.param: An object to use as the cursor.
member.remarks: must already be initialized to contain the cursors of the arrays in . There must be at least one member array, and all member arrays must have the same dimensions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.ICommunicator.Alltoall``1(``0[])
member.summary: Collective operation in which every process sends data to every other process. Alltoall differs from Allgather<T>(T) in that a given process can send different data to all of the other processes, rather than contributing the same piece of data to all processes.
member.typeparam: Any serializable type.
member.param: The array of values that will be sent to each process. The ith value in this array will be sent to the process with rank i.
member.returns: An array of values received from all of the other processes. The jth value in this array will be the value sent to the calling process from the process with rank j.

members.member:
Collective operation in which every process sends data to every other process. Alltoall differs from Allgather<T>(T) in that a given process can send different data to all of the other processes, rather than contributing the same piece of data to all processes.
Any serializable type.
The array of values that will be sent to each process. sendCounts[i] worth of data will be sent to process i.
The numbers of items to be sent to each process.
The numbers of items to be received by each process.
The array of values received from all of the other processes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.ICommunicator.Allreduce``1(``0,System.Func{``0,``0,``0})
member.summary:
Allreduce is a collective algorithm that combines the values stored by each process into a single value available to all processes. The values are combined in a user-defined way, specified via a delegate. If value1, value2, ..., valueN are the values provided by the N processes in the communicator, the result will be the value value1 op value2 op ... op valueN.
An Allreduce is equivalent to a Reduce<T>(T, MPI.ReductionOperation<T>, int) followed by a Broadcast<T>(ref T, int)
member.typeparam: Any serializable type.
member.param: The local value that will be combined with the values provided by other processes.
The operation used to combine two values. This operation must be associative.
member.returns: The result of the reduction. The same value will be returned to all processes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.ICommunicator.Reduce``1(``0,System.Func{``0,``0,``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Reduce is a collective algorithm that combines the values stored by each process into a single value available at the designated process. The values are combined in a user-defined way, specified via a delegate. If value1, value2, ..., valueN are the values provided by the N processes in the communicator, the result will be the value value1 op value2 op ... op valueN. This result is only available to the process.
member.typeparam: Any serializable type.
member.param: The local value that will be combined with the values provided by other processes.
The operation used to combine two values. This operation must be associative.
The rank of the process that is the root of the reduction operation, which will receive the result of the reduction operation.
member.returns: On the root, returns the result of the reduction operation. The other processes receive a default value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.IGeneratedAlgorithm
member.summary: Interface for running a generated inference algorithm

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.IGeneratedAlgorithm.NumberOfIterationsDone
member.summary: The number of iterations done from the initial state or since the last change of observed values
member.remarks: Changing an observed value will reset this to 0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.IGeneratedAlgorithm.Execute(System.Int32)
member.summary: Execute the inference algorithm for the specified number of iterations, starting from the initial state
member.param: The number of iterations to perform from the initial state
member.remarks: Sets NumberOfIterationsDone = . This method is equivalent to calling Reset() followed by Update(numberOfIterations).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.IGeneratedAlgorithm.Update(System.Int32)
member.summary: Perform additional iterations of the inference algorithm
member.param: The number of additional iterations to perform
member.remarks: If no observed values have changed, this method increments NumberOfIterationsDone by , and is equivalent to calling Execute(NumberOfIterationsDone + additionalIterations). If some observed values have changed, this method sets NumberOfIterationsDone = , and is not equivalent to calling Execute, because it will start from the existing message state rather than the initial state.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.IGeneratedAlgorithm.Reset
member.summary: Reset all messages to their initial values. Sets NumberOfIterationsDone to 0
member.remarks: This method is equivalent to calling Execute(0)

member.remarks: Execute, Update, or Reset must be called first to set the value of the marginal.

member.summary: Constructs a vector by referencing an array.
member.param: The number of elements in the vector.
The starting index in the array for the vector elements.

remarks.para: The vector will not copy the array but only reference it, so any numerical changes to the array will also apply to the vector. If the array grows larger, the extra elements are ignored. The array must not shrink or else the vector will become inconsistent.
Throws an exception if Data is null, start < 0, or count < 0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.DenseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this vector and another vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.DenseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.DenseVector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this dense vector and another dense vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.DenseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.DenseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.DenseVector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this dense vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.LowerTriangularMatrix.SetToCholesky(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Matrix)
member.summary: Gets the Cholesky decomposition L, such that L*L' = A.
member.returns: True if is positive definite, otherwise false.
member.remarks: The decomposition is a lower triangular matrix L, returned in this. must be symmetric, but need not be positive definite. If is positive semidefinite, then L will satisfy L*L' = A. Otherwise, L will only approximately satisfy L*L' = A.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Matrix.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Matrix)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between matrix elements.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i,j] - that[i,j])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and that are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Matrix.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Matrix,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between matrix elements.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i,j] - that[i,j])/(abs(this[i,j]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and that are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.PiecewiseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this vector and another vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.PiecewiseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Rand.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Generates a random sample from a Gamma distribution.
member.param: The shape parameter. Must be finite and > 0.
member.returns: A nonnegative finite real number. May be zero.
member.remarks: The distribution is defined as p(x) = x^(a-1)*exp(-x)/Gamma(a). To incorporate a scale parameter b, multiply the result by b.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Rand.Wishart(System.Double,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.LowerTriangularMatrix)
member.summary: Generates a random sample from a Wishart distribution.
member.param: The shape parameter. Must be finite and > 0.
Receives the lower triangular Cholesky factor of the sampled matrix. Must be non-null, square, and already allocated to the desired size.

remarks.para: The Wishart distribution is defined as
p(X) = |X|^((n-d-1)/2)*exp(-tr(X))/Gamma_d(n/2) (using parameter n)
or
p(X) = |X|^(a-(d+1)/2)*exp(-tr(X))/Gamma_d(a) (using parameter a)

This routine returns chol(X). To incorporate a scale parameter C, set Y = chol(C)*X*chol(C)', which implies chol(Y) = chol(C)*chol(X). If you invert and transpose chol(X), then you have chol(inv(X)), where inv(X) is a sample from the inverse Wishart distribution:
p(X) = |X|^(-a-(d+1)/2)*exp(-tr(inv(X)))/Gamma_d(a)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.SparseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this vector and another vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.SparseVector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath
member.summary: This class provides mathematical constants and special functions, analogous to System.Math. It cannot be instantiated and consists of static members only.

remarks.para: In order to provide the highest accuracy, some routines return their results in log form or logit form. These transformations expand the domain to cover the full range of double-precision values, ensuring all bits of the representation are utilized. A good example of this is the NormalCdf function, whose value lies between 0 and 1. Numbers between 0 and 1 use only a small fraction of the capacity of a double-precision number. The function NormalCdfLogit transforms the result p according to log(p/(1-p)), providing full use of the range from -Infinity to Infinity and (potentially) much higher precision.

To get maximal use out of these transformations, you want to stay in the expanded form as long as possible. Every time you transform into a smaller domain, you lose precision. Thus helper functions are provided which allow you to perform common tasks directly in the log form and logit form. For logs, you have addition. For logit, you have averaging.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.BesselI(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Modified Bessel function of the first kind
member.param: Order parameter. Any real number except a negative integer.

member.remarks: Reference: "A short note on parameter approximation for von Mises-Fisher distributions, And a fast implementation of Is(x)" Suvrit Sra Computational Statistics, 2011 http://people.kyb.tuebingen.mpg.de/suvrit/papers/vmfFinal.pdf
member.returns: BesselI(a,x)

The second argument - any real number greater than 0.
The third argument - any real number greater than 0.
A tolerance for terminating the series calculation.
member.returns: The incomplete beta function at (, , ).
member.remarks: The beta function is obtained by setting x to 1.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates Gamma(x), defined as the integral from 0 to x of t^(x-1)*exp(-t) dt.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Digamma(System.Double)

member.summary: Coefficients of de Moivre's expansion for the digamma function. Each coefficient is B_{2j}/(2j) where B_{2j} are the Bernoulli numbers, starting from j=1

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Trigamma(System.Double)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfRatioDiff_Simple(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes NormalCdfRatio(x+delta)-NormalCdfRatio(x) given NormalCdfRatio(x). Is inaccurate for x < -17. For more accuracy, use NormalCdfRatioDiff.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfRatioDiff(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfMomentRatioDiff(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes NormalCdfMomentRatio(n, x+delta)-NormalCdfMomentRatio(n, x)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdf(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the cumulative Gaussian distribution, defined as the integral from -infinity to x of N(t;0,1) dt. For example, NormalCdf(0) == 0.5.
member.returns: The cumulative Gaussian distribution at .

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfLn(System.Double)
member.summary: The natural logarithm of the cumulative Gaussian distribution.
member.returns: ln(NormalCdf(x)).
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than Math.Log(NormalCdf(x)), which can fail for x < -7.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfLogit(System.Double)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfInv(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the inverse of the cumulative Gaussian distribution, i.e. NormalCdf(NormalCdfInv(p)) == p. For example, NormalCdfInv(0.5) == 0. This is also known as the Gaussian quantile function.
member.returns: A number x such that NormalCdf(x) == p.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfMomentRatio(System.Int32,System.Double)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfMomentRatioRecurrence(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes int_0^infinity t^n N(t;x,1) dt / (n! N(x;0,1))

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfMomentRatioTaylor(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compute int_0^infinity t^n N(t;x,1) dt / (n! N(x;0,1)) by Taylor expansion around x0

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfMomentRatioTaylor(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double[])
member.summary: Compute int_0^infinity t^n N(t;x,1) dt / (n! N(x;0,1)) by Taylor expansion given pre-computed derivatives

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfMomentRatioConFrac(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes int_0^infinity t^n N(t;x,1) dt / (n! N(x;0,1))

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfDiff(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes NormalCdf(x) - NormalCdf(y) to high accuracy.
member.returns: The difference.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdf(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the cumulative bivariate normal distribution.
member.remarks: The cumulative bivariate normal distribution is defined as int_(-inf)^x int_(-inf)^y N([x;y],[0;0],[1 r; r 1]) dx dy where N([x;y],[0;0],[1 r; r 1]) = exp(-0.5*(x^2+y^2-2*x*y*r)/(1-r^2))/(2*pi*sqrt(1-r^2)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfExtended(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the cumulative Gaussian distribution, defined as the integral from -infinity to x of N(t;0,1) dt. For example, NormalCdf(0) == 0.5.
member.returns: The cumulative Gaussian distribution at .

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfExtended(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the cumulative bivariate normal distribution.
member.remarks: The cumulative bivariate normal distribution is defined as int_(-inf)^x int_(-inf)^y N([x;y],[0;0],[1 r; r 1]) dx dy where N([x;y],[0;0],[1 r; r 1]) = exp(-0.5*(x^2+y^2-2*x*y*r)/(1-r^2))/(2*pi*sqrt(1-r^2)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfLn(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the natural logarithm of the cumulative bivariate normal distribution.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfRatioLn(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the natural logarithm of the cumulative bivariate normal distribution, minus the log-density of the bivariate normal distribution at x and y, plus 0.5*log(1-r*r).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfRatioConFrac(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns NormalCdf divided by N(x;0,1) N((y-rx)/sqrt(1-r^2);0,1), multiplied by scale. If r == -1, then divides by N(min(x,y);0,1) instead. If integral==true, returns NormalCdfIntegral divided by N(x;0,1) N((y-rx)/sqrt(1-r^2);0,1), multiplied by scale

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfIntegral(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the integral of the cumulative bivariate normal distribution wrt x.
member.returns: r such that r*exp(exponent) is the integral

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfIntegralRatio(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.NormalCdfIntegralRatio(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the integral of the cumulative bivariate normal distribution wrt x, divided by the cumulative bivariate normal distribution.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.OneMinusSqrtOneMinus(System.Double)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Logistic(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logistic function 1/(1+exp(-x)).
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogisticLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Compute the natural logarithm of the logistic function, i.e. -log(1+exp(-x)).
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: -log(1+exp(-x)).
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of -log(1+exp(-x)), which can fail for x < -50 and x > 36.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Log1Plus(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the natural logarithm of 1+x.
member.param: A real number in the range -1 <= x <= Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(1+x), which is always >= 0.
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(1+x), particularly when is small.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogRatio(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(numerator/denominator) to high accuracy.
member.returns: log(numerator/denominator)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Log1PlusExp(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(1 + exp(x)) to high accuracy.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(1+exp(x)), which is always >= 0.
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(1+exp(x)), particularly when x < -36 or x > 50.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Log1MinusExp(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(1 - exp(x)) to high accuracy.
member.param: A non-positive real number: -Inf <= x <= 0, or NaN.
member.returns: log(1-exp(x)), which is always <= 0.
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(1-exp(x)), particularly when x < -7.5 or x > -1e-5.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.ExpMinus1(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the exponential of x and subtracts 1.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: exp(x)-1
member.remarks: This function is more accurate than a direct evaluation of exp(x)-1 when x is small. It is the inverse function to Log1Plus: ExpMinus1(Log1Plus(x)) == x.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.ExpMinus1RatioMinus1RatioMinusHalf(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes ((exp(x)-1)/x - 1)/x - 0.5
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogExpMinus1(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(exp(x)-1) for non-negative x.
member.param: A non-negative real number: 0 <= x <= Inf, or NaN.
member.remarks: This function is more accurate than a direct evaluation of log(exp(x)-1) when x < 1e-3 or x > 50. It is the inverse function to Log1PlusExp: LogExpMinus1(Log1PlusExp(x)) == x.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogDifferenceOfExp(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(exp(x) - exp(y)) to high accuracy.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN. Must be greater or equal to y.
Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN. Must be less or equal to x.
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(exp(x)-exp(y)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.DifferenceOfExp(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes exp(x)-exp(y) to high accuracy.
member.returns: exp(x)-exp(y)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogSumExp(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(exp(x) + exp(y)) to high accuracy.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(exp(x)+exp(y)), which is always >= max(x,y).
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of log(exp(x)+exp(y)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogSumExp(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Returns the log of the sum of exponentials of a list of doubles

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogSumExpSparse(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Returns the log of the sum of exponentials of a list of doubles

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.DiffLogSumExp(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes log(exp(x)+exp(a))-log(exp(x)+exp(b)) to high accuracy.
member.param: Any real number from -Inf to Inf, or NaN.
member.returns: log(exp(x)+exp(a))-log(exp(x)+exp(b))
member.remarks: This function provides higher accuracy than a direct evaluation of LogSumExp(x,a)-LogSumExp(x,b), particularly when x is large.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Logit(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the log-odds function log(p/(1-p)).
member.returns: log(p/(1-p))
member.remarks: This function is the inverse of the logistic function, i.e. Logistic(Logit(p)) == p.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogitFromLog(System.Double)
member.summary: Compute log(p/(1-p)) from log(p).
member.returns: log(exp(logp)/(1-exp(logp))) = -log(exp(-logp)-1).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Softmax(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Exponentiate array elements and normalize to sum to 1.
member.returns: A Vector p where p[k] = exp(x[k])/sum_j exp(x[j])
member.remarks: Sparse lists and vectors are handled efficiently

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Log1PlusExpGaussian(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates E[log(1+exp(x))] under a Gaussian distribution with specified mean and variance.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogisticGaussianQuadratureNodeCount
member.summary: Specifies the number of quadrature nodes that should be used when doing Gauss Hermite quadrature for direct KL minimisation

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogisticGaussianVarianceThreshold
member.summary: For integrals with variance greater than this Clenshaw curtis quadrature will be used instead of Gauss-Hermite quadrature.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogisticGaussian(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate sigma(m,v) = \int N(x;m,v) logistic(x) dx
member.returns: The value of this special function.

remarks.para: Note 1-LogisticGaussian(m,v) = LogisticGaussian(-m,v) which is more accurate.

For large v we can use the big v approximation \sigma(m,v)=normcdf(m/sqrt(v+pi^2/3)). For small and moderate v we use Gauss-Hermite quadrature. For moderate v we first find the mode of the (log concave) function since this may be quite far from m.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogisticGaussianDerivative(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate \sigma'(m,v)=\int N(x;m,v)logistic'(x) dx
member.returns: The value of this special function.

remarks.para: For large v we can use the big v approximation \sigma'(m,v)=N(m,0,v+pi^2/3). For small and moderate v we use Gauss-Hermite quadrature. For moderate v we first find the mode of the (log concave) function since this may be quite far from m.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogisticGaussianDerivative2(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate \sigma''(m,v)=\int N(x;m,v)logistic''(x) dx
member.returns: The value of this special function.

remarks.para: For large v we can use the big v approximation \sigma'(m,v)=-m/(v+pi^2/3)*N(m,0,v+pi^2/3). For small and moderate v we use Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The function is multimodal so mode finding is difficult and probably won't help.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.LogisticGaussianRatio(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate (kth derivative of LogisticGaussian)*exp(0.5*mean^2/variance)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.MMath.Ulp(System.Double)

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Sparsity
member.summary: Defines sparsity settings for vectors. The sparsity handling has been designed to deal with large dimensional distributions such as Discrete and Dirichlet distributions.

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Sparsity.Sparse
member.summary: Static read-only property giving Sparsity settings for sparse, exact vectors.
member.remarks: A vector class which uses this sparsity will maintain a common background value. It is expected that only a small percentage of values will differ from this common value, and this enables the vector class to be efficient computationally and memory-wise. uses this specification.

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Sparsity.Piecewise
member.summary: Static read-only property giving Sparsity settings for piecewise, exact vectors.
member.remarks: A vector class which uses this sparsity is expected to have ranges of elements that have the same values. uses this specification.

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Sparsity.Dense
member.summary: Static read-only property giving Sparsity settings for dense vectors.
member.remarks: uses this specification.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Sparsity.ApproximateWithTolerance(System.Double)
member.summary: Static read-only property giving Sparsity settings for approximate vector with the given tolerance.
member.param: At what tolerance are vector values considered equal to the common value.
member.remarks: supports this specification.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.StorageType
member.summary: The type of storage used in a vector, which is specified as part of the Sparsity class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.StorageType.Dense
member.summary: The vector is stored as a dense array with memory allocated for each element.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.StorageType.Sparse
member.summary: The vector is stored as a sparse array with memory allocated only for elements that do not have a particular common value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.StorageType.Piecewise
member.summary: The vector is stored as a set of pieces with each piece having a constant value, and all elements not in any piece having a particular common value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector
member.summary: Base class for vectors. , , and all inherit from this base class.
member.remarks: This class includes factory methods for instantiating Vectors of different specifications. Beyond this initial construction, application code does not need to know the the sparsity, and most operations can be done via this general base class which will handle sparsity correctly.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Returns the maximum absolute difference between this vector and another vector.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector.MaxDiff(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the maximum relative difference between this vector and another.
member.param: An offset to avoid division by zero.
member.returns: max(abs(this[i] - that[i])/(abs(this[i]) + rel)). Matching infinities or NaNs do not count. If this and are not the same size, returns infinity.
member.remarks: This routine is typically used instead of Equals, since Equals is susceptible to roundoff errors.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipAttribute
member.summary: The result is always uniform.
member.remarks: Applies to message functions. This annotation is optional and allows the inference engine to skip unnecessary function calls, i.e. ones which would produce uniform results.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfUniformAttribute
member.summary: The result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) whenever this parameter is uniform, hence the function call can be skipped.

remarks.para: Applies to message function parameters. This annotation is optional and allows the inference engine to skip unnecessary function calls, i.e. ones which would produce a uniform result or throw an exception. For LogAverageFactor and AverageLogFactor, SkipIfUniform means the result would be 0.

When applied to an array parameter, this attribute means the result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) whenever all dependent elements in the array are uniform. For example:
f([AllExceptIndex,SkipIfUniform] Message[] array, int resultIndex) f depends on all elements other than resultIndex, and can be skipped if all of these are uniform. f does not depend on array[resultIndex] and the uniformity of this element is ignored.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfAllUniformAttribute
member.summary: The result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) if all elements are uniform, hence the function call can be skipped.

remarks.para: Applies to message functions and message function array parameters. This annotation is optional and allows the inference engine to skip unnecessary function calls, i.e. ones which would produce a uniform result or throw an exception. When applied to a message function, it means that the result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) whenever all parameters to the function are uniform. When applied to an array parameter, it means that the result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) whenever all dependent elements in the array are uniform. Array elements that the function does not depend on are ignored.

It only makes sense to apply this attribute to a method when the method parameters have no SkipIfUniform attributes set. Otherwise SkipIfAllUniform is automatically implied by SkipIfUniform for the parameter.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfAllUniformAttribute.ParameterNames
member.summary: List of parameter names for which to check for uniformity

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfAllUniformAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new SkipIfAllUniform attribute

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfAllUniformAttribute.#ctor(System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new SkipIfAllUniform attribute applied to the specified parameter names

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfAnyUniformAttribute
member.summary: The result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) if any element is uniform, hence the function call can be skipped.

remarks.para: Applies to message function array parameters. This annotation is optional and allows the inference engine to skip unnecessary function calls, i.e. ones which would produce a uniform result or throw an exception. When applied to an array parameter, it means that the result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) whenever any dependent element in the array is uniform. Array elements that the function does not depend on are ignored. When applied to a parameter that is not an array, it has the same meaning as SkipIfUniform.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfAnyExceptIndexIsUniformAttribute
member.summary: The result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) if any element except at the result index is uniform, hence the function call can be skipped.
member.remarks:
Examples:
f([SkipIfAnyExceptIndexIsUniform] Message[] array, int resultIndex) Since no dependency attribute was given, the default is that f depends on all elements of the array. Since SkipIfAnyExceptIndexIsUniform was given, f returns uniform (or throws an exception) if any elements except the one at resultIndex is uniform. Thus array[resultIndex] is a dependency but its uniformity is ignored.
f([AllExceptIndex,SkipIfAnyExceptIndexIsUniform] Message[] array, int resultIndex) In this case, f depends on all elements other than resultIndex, and returns uniform (or throws an exception) if any of them are uniform. Thus it is equivalent to [AllExceptIndex,SkipIfUniform]
f([MatchingIndex,SkipIfAnyExceptIndexIsUniform] Message[] array, int resultIndex) Here SkipIfAnyExceptIndexIsUniform is ignored since f only depends on array[resultIndex].
This attribute can be stacked with the other SkipIfUniform attributes, to build up a set of skip cases.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfAllExceptIndexAreUniformAttribute
member.summary: The result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) if all elements except at the result index are uniform, hence the function call can be skipped.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.SkipIfMatchingIndexIsUniformAttribute
member.summary: The result is uniform (or an exception would be thrown) if the element at the result index is uniform, hence the function call can be skipped.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.IgnoreDependencyAttribute
member.summary: When attached to a method parameter, indicates that the dependency should be ignored by the FactorManager. Only a declaration dependency will be retained.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.IgnoreDeclarationAttribute
member.summary: When attached to a method parameter, indicates that the dependency and the declaration dependency should be ignored by the FactorManager.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.ConstantAttribute
member.summary: When attached to a factor parameter, indicates that the parameter is constant - i.e. cannot be changed by observation or by inference

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.ConstantAttribute.IsDefined(System.Reflection.ParameterInfo)
member.summary: Returns true if this parameter has a Constant attribute

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.RequiredArgumentAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument, indicates that argument is required to have been set before calling the method

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.IsReturnedAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument, indicates that the argument will be returned unmodified as the result of the method. This automatically implies SkipIfUniform and Trigger.
member.remarks: This attribute allows significant optimisations to be undertaken in the compiler.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.IsReturnedInEveryElementAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument for methods that return lists, indicates that all elements of the returned list will be identical and equal to that argument. This automatically implies SkipIfUniform.
member.remarks: This attribute allows significant optimisations to be undertaken in the compiler.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.TriggerAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument, indicates that the method's result is invalidated when a dependent item in that argument changes.
member.remarks: The formal definition of trigger is: If C uses A, and A is triggered by B, then when B changes, A must be updated before C.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.MatchingIndexTriggerAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument, indicates that the method's result is invalidated when the array element at resultIndex changes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.NoTriggersAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method, indicates that no default triggers should be assigned to its parameters. The method will explicitly mark its triggers using TriggerAttribute. A general rule is that a VMP operator that depends on the opposite message must not trigger on that message (i.e. non-conjugate operators).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.FreshAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument, indicates that the argument must be up-to-date before invoking the method. When applied to a method, indicates that the method must be recomputed whenever any of its arguments change.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.MultiplyAllAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a message function, indicates that the function returns the product of its arguments.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.NoInitAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument, indicates that the argument does not benefit from initialization (by default, initialization is assumed to be beneficial). This attribute is incompatible with SkipIfUniform or Required.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.DiodeAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method argument, indicates that the argument should not participate in backward sequential loops.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.ReturnsCompositeArrayAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a factor, indicates that the factor returns a composite array.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.NotSupportedAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a method, indicates that the method will always throw a NotSupportedException.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.NotSupportedAttribute.Message
member.summary: Message for the exception that will be thrown by the method

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.NotSupportedAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a NotSupported attribute with the given exception message

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.QualityBand
member.summary: Quality bands for Infer.NET components - distributions, operators, factors

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.QualityBand.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown. Components which are not marked with a quality band.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.QualityBand.Experimental
member.summary: Experimental components are work in progress and represent early stage development of new components. They are typically usable in just a few common scenarios, and will not have undergone rigorous testing. They are primarily intended for use by researchers and provide an opportunity for preliminary feedback. It is possible that a given experimental component may not be included in a future release. These may be undocumented or only sparsely documented.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.QualityBand.Preview
member.summary: Preview components are intended to meet most basic usage scenarios. While in the Preview Quality Band, these components may have a moderate number of breaking API or behavior changes in response to user feedback and as we learn more about how they will be used. Users are likely to encounter bugs and functionality issues for less common scenarios. These will have some documentation which may be minimal.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.QualityBand.Stable
member.summary: Stable components are suitable for a wide range of usage scenarios and will have incorporated substantial design and functionality feedback. They may continue evolving via limited bug fixes, fine-tuning, and support for additional scenarios. Stable components may have a small number of breaking API or behaviour changes when feedback demands it. These components will have reasonable documentation which may include examples.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.QualityBand.Mature
member.summary: Mature components are ready for full release, meeting the highest levels of quality and stability. Future releases of mature components will maintain a high quality bar with no breaking changes other than in exceptional circumstances. Users should be confident using mature components, knowing that when they upgrade from one version of Infer.NET to a newer version it will be a quick and easy process. These components will have detailed documentation and at least one example of usage.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.Quality
member.summary: Attribute used to label Infer.NET components. They may be attached to algorithm classes, distribution classes, and operator classes. They may also be attached to any methods on these classes
member.remarks:
Methods inherit the quality of their class. Classes are, by default, experimental.
The compiler will convert static quality bands to a quality band for each generated statement of code. Depending on the error level and warning levels set in the compiler, Errors and/or warnings will be issued. In addition, a general warning/error may be issued for the algorithm.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Attributes.Quality.Band
member.summary: Quality band

member.summary: VMP message to a.
member.param: Incoming message from areEqual. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except a. Because the factor is deterministic, areEqual is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_areEqual p(areEqual) factor(areEqual,a,b))).

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of sample as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(logOdds) p(logOdds) factor(sample,logOdds)]/p(sample).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.BernoulliFromLogOddsOp.AverageLogFactor(System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.returns: Average of the factor's log-value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(sample,logOdds)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.BernoulliFromLogOddsOp.SampleAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to sample.
member.param: Incoming message from logOdds. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.BernoulliFromLogOddsOp.LogOddsAverageLogarithm(System.Boolean,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Gradient matching VMP message from factor to logOdds variable
member.param: Incoming message. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Previous message sent, used for damping
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the Gaussian approximation to the factor which results in the same derivatives of the KL(q||p) divergence with respect to the parameters of the posterior as if the true factor had been used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.BinomialOp.SampleAverageConditional(System.Double,System.Int32,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: EP message to binomial.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of binomial conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.BinomialOp.SampleAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Beta,System.Int32,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: EP message to binomial.
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of binomial as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(binomial) sum_(p) p(p) factor(binomial,n,p)]/p(binomial).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ConcatOp.FirstAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to first.
member.param: Incoming message from concat. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of first with concat integrated out. The formula is sum_concat p(concat) factor(concat,first,second).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ConcatOp.FirstAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to first.
member.param: Incoming message from concat. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except first. Because the factor is deterministic, concat is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(second) p(second) log(sum_concat p(concat) factor(concat,first,second))).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.CopyOp`1.AverageLogFactor(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.TruncatedGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.returns: Zero.

remarks.para: In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero. Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

This factor is implicitly maintaining the truncated Gaussian variational posterior. Therefore we need to remove the entropy of the Gaussian representation, and add the entropy for the truncated Gaussian

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.CountTrueOp.CountAverageConditional(System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: EP message to count.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the count argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of count conditioned on the given values.
Marginal distribution of count is known as Poisson Binomial. It can be found in O(n^2) time using dynamic programming, where n is the length of the array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.CountTrueOp.ArrayAverageConditional``1(``0,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete,System.Double[0:,0:],``0)
member.summary: EP message to array.
member.param: Incoming message from count. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of array as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(array) sum_(count) p(count) factor(count,array)]/p(array).

Poison Binomial for a given list of Bernoulli random variables with one variable excluded can be computed in linear time given Poisson Binomial for the whole list of items computed in a forward pass, as well as a special table containing averaged Poisson Binomial, which can be computed in a backward pass. Both tables can be computed in O(n^2) time, where n is a size of the list, so the time complexity of this message operator is also O(n^2).

member.typeparam: The type of messages from/to 'array'.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.CountTrueOp.ArrayAverageConditional``1(``0,System.Int32,System.Double[0:,0:],``0)

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of array conditioned on the given values.

member.typeparam: The type of messages from/to 'array'.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.CountTrueOp.PoissonBinomialForwardPass(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli})
member.summary: Compute Poisson Binomial table for a given list of Bernoulli-distributed random variables in a forward pass.
member.returns: Table A, such that A[i, j] = P(sum([1], ..., [i]) = j).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.CountTrueOp.AveragedPoissonBinomialBackwardPassTableRows(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli},Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Enumerate rows of averaged Poisson Binomial table for a given list of Bernoulli-distributed random variables in a backward pass.
member.param: Distribution over sum of values in used to average the Poisson Binomial.

returns.para: Rows of table A, such that A[i, j] = \sum_c P( = c) P(sum([i + 1], ..., [n]) + j = c). Rows are returned last-to-first, the very first row is omitted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.DirichletSymmetricOp.AlphaAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: VMP message to alpha.
member.param: Incoming message from prob. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from alpha. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the alpha argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except alpha. The formula is exp(sum_(prob) p(prob) log(factor(prob,K,alpha))).
Optimal message calculated by minimising local KL divergence using LBFGS.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.DirichletOp.TotalCountAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: VMP message to totalCount.
member.param: Incoming message from totalCount. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from prob. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the totalCount argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except totalCount. The formula is exp(sum_(prob) p(prob) log(factor(prob,mean,totalCount))).
The outgoing message here would not be Dirichlet distributed, so we use Nonconjugate VMP, which sends the approximate factor ensuring the gradient of the KL wrt to the variational parameters match.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.DirichletOp.TotalCountAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)

member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the totalCount argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except totalCount. The formula is exp(sum_(mean,prob) p(mean,prob) log(factor(prob,mean,totalCount))).
The outgoing message here would not be Dirichlet distributed, so we use Nonconjugate VMP, which sends the approximate factor ensuring the gradient of the KL wrt to the variational parameters match.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.DirichletOp.TotalCountAverageLogarithmHelper(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: VMP message to 'totalCount'. This functionality is separated out to allow use by BetaOp.
member.param: Pseudocount of incoming message from 'mean'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from 'totalCount'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
E[log(prob)] from incoming message from 'prob'. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.

remarks.para: The outgoing message here would not be Dirichlet distributed, so we use Nonconjugate VMP, which sends the approximate factor ensuring the gradient of the KL wrt to the variational parameters match.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.DirichletOp.MeanMessageExpectations(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Perform the quadrature required for the Nonconjugate VMP message to 'mean'
member.param: Array to be filled with E[LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[Log(m_k)*LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[Log(1-m_k)*LogGamma(s*m_k)].

remarks.para: All three arrays are calculated simultaneously for efficiency. The quadrature over 'totalCount' (which is Gamma-distributed) is performed by a change of variable x=log(s) followed by Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The quadrature over m is performed using Gauss-Legendre.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.DirichletOp.TotalCountMessageExpectations(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Perform the quadrature required for the Nonconjugate VMP message to 'totalCount'
member.param: Array to be filled with E[LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[Log(s)*LogGamma(s*m_k)].
Array to be filled with E[s*m_k*Digamma(s*m_k)].

remarks.para: All three arrays are calculated simultaneously for efficiency. The quadrature over 'totalCount' (which is Gamma-distributed) is peformed by a change of variable x=log(s) followed by Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The quadrature over m is performed using Gauss-Legendre.

member.summary: Perform the quadrature required for the VMP evidence message
member.returns: Vector of E[ LogGamma(s*m_k)].

remarks.para: The quadrature over 'totalCount' (which is Gamma-distributed) is peformed by a change of variable x=log(s) followed by Gauss-Hermite quadrature. The quadrature over m is performed using Gauss-Legendre.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(exp,d)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(exp) p(exp) factor(exp,d)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ExpOp.LogEvidenceRatio(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(exp,d) p(exp,d) factor(exp,d) / sum_exp p(exp) messageTo(exp)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ExpOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Double,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(d) p(d) factor(exp,d)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ExpOp.ExpAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: EP message to exp.
member.param: Incoming message from d. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the exp argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of exp as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(exp) sum_(d) p(d) factor(exp,d)]/p(exp).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ExpOp.DAverageConditional(System.Double)
member.summary: EP message to d.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the d argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of d conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ExpOp.DNonconjugateAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.NonconjugateGaussian)
member.summary: Nonconjugate VMP message to 'd'.
member.param: Incoming message from 'exp'. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing nonconjugate VMP message to the 'd' argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the integral of the log-factor times incoming messages, over all arguments except 'd'. The formula is int log(f(d,x)) q(x) dx where x = (exp).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GammaFromShapeAndRateOpBase.LogEvidenceRatio(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sample) p(sample) factor(sample,shape,rate) / sum_sample p(sample) messageTo(sample)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GammaFromShapeAndRateOpBase.SampleAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: EP message to sample.
member.param: Incoming message from shape. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from rate. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the sample argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of sample as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(shape,rate) p(shape,rate) factor(sample,shape,rate)]/p(sample).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GateEnterPartialOp`1.ValueAverageLogarithm``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete,System.Int32[],``0)
member.summary: VMP message to value.
member.param: Incoming message from enterPartial. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except value. Because the factor is deterministic, enterPartial is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(selector) p(selector) log(sum_enterPartial p(enterPartial) factor(enterPartial,selector,value,indices))).

member.typeparam: The type of the distribution over the variable entering the gate.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except case0. member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Double,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.param: Incoming message from mean. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(mean,precision) p(mean,precision) factor(sample,mean,precision)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Double,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.param: Incoming message from mean. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from precision. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(mean,precision) p(mean,precision) factor(sample,mean,precision)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.summary: Evidence message for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp.SampleAverageLogarithm(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: VMP message to sample.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the sample argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of sample conditioned on the given values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp.SampleAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,System.Double)
member.summary: VMP message to sample.
member.param: Incoming message from mean. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the sample argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except sample. The formula is exp(sum_(mean) p(mean) log(factor(sample,mean,precision))).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp_Slow
member.summary:
Provides outgoing messages for the following factors:
, given random arguments to the function.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp_Slow.SampleAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)
member.summary: EP message to sample.
member.param: Incoming message from mean. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from precision. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the sample argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of sample as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(mean,precision) p(mean,precision) factor(sample,mean,precision)]/p(sample).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp_Slow.PrecisionAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma)

Incoming message from precision. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the precision argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of precision as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(precision) sum_(sample,mean) p(sample,mean) factor(sample,mean,precision)]/p(precision).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianOp_PointPrecision
member.summary: This class defines specializations for the case where precision is a point mass. These methods have fewer inputs, allowing more efficient schedules.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GetItemOp`1
member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.
member.typeparam: The type of an item.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GetItemOp`1.LogAverageFactor(`0,System.Collections.Generic.IList{`0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(item,array) p(item,array) factor(item,array,index)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GetItemOp`1.LogEvidenceRatio(`0,System.Collections.Generic.IList{`0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(item,array) p(item,array) factor(item,array,index) / sum_item p(item) messageTo(item)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GetItemOp`1.AverageLogFactor(`0,System.Collections.Generic.IList{`0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.returns: Zero.

remarks.para: In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero. Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GetItemOp`1.ItemAverageConditional``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Int32,``0)
member.summary: EP message to item.
member.param: Incoming message from array. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of item as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(item) sum_(array) p(array) factor(item,array,index)]/p(item).

member.typeparam: The type of the distribution over an item.

member.typeparam: The type of the distribution over an item.

member.summary: EP message to list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.IndexOfMaximumOp.LogAverageFactor``1(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.IndexOfMaximumBuffer,``0,System.Int32)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(list) p(list) factor(indexOfMaximumDouble,list)).

member.typeparam: The type of an incoming message from list.

member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(list) p(list) factor(indexOfMaximumDouble,list)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.summary: EP message to indexOfMaximumDouble.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the indexOfMaximumDouble argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of indexOfMaximumDouble as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(indexOfMaximumDouble) sum_(list) p(list) factor(indexOfMaximumDouble,list)]/p(indexOfMaximumDouble).

member.typeparam: The type of an incoming message from list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.IndexOfMaximumStochasticOp.LogAverageFactor``1(``0,``0,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.IndexOfMaximumBuffer[],Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.param: Incoming message from list. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(list,indexOfMaximumDouble) p(list,indexOfMaximumDouble) factor(indexOfMaximumDouble,list)).

member.typeparam: The type of an incoming message from list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.IndexOfMaximumStochasticOp.LogEvidenceRatio``1(``0,``0,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.IndexOfMaximumBuffer[])
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(list,indexOfMaximumDouble) p(list,indexOfMaximumDouble) factor(indexOfMaximumDouble,list) / sum_indexOfMaximumDouble p(indexOfMaximumDouble) messageTo(indexOfMaximumDouble)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.typeparam: The type of an incoming message from list.
