member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductOp
member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductOp.InnerProductAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: EP message to innerProduct.
member.param: Incoming message from a. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from b. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the innerProduct argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of innerProduct as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(innerProduct) sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(innerProduct,a,b)]/p(innerProduct).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductOp.AAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: EP message to a.
member.param: Incoming message from b. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of a as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(a) sum_(innerProduct,b) p(innerProduct,b) factor(innerProduct,a,b)]/p(a).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductOp.BAverageConditional(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: EP message to b.
member.param: Incoming message from a. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of b as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(b) sum_(innerProduct,a) p(innerProduct,a) factor(innerProduct,a,b)]/p(b).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductOp.LogAverageFactor(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(innerProduct,a,b) p(innerProduct,a,b) factor(innerProduct,a,b)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Double,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(a,b) p(a,b) factor(innerProduct,a,b)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductOp.LogEvidenceRatio(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(innerProduct,a,b) p(innerProduct,a,b) factor(innerProduct,a,b) / sum_innerProduct p(innerProduct) messageTo(innerProduct)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductPartialCovarianceOp.MeanOfB(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.PositiveDefiniteMatrix,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Update the buffer MeanOfB.
member.param: Incoming message from B. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

member.summary: VMP message to A.
member.param: Incoming message from X. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from B. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except A. Because the factor is deterministic, X is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(B) p(B) log(sum_X p(X) factor(X,A,B))).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.InnerProductPartialCovarianceOp.BAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,System.Double[],Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to B.
member.param: Incoming message from X. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the factor viewed as a function of B with X integrated out. The formula is sum_X p(X) factor(X,A,B).

member.summary: VMP message to B.
member.param: Incoming message from X. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from A. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except B. Because the factor is deterministic, X is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(A) p(A) log(sum_X p(X) factor(X,A,B))).

member.param: Incoming message from B. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the X argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of X as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(B) p(B) factor(X,A,B)].

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.IsGreaterThanOp.AAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete)
member.summary: VMP message to a.
member.param: Incoming message from isGreaterThan. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except a. Because the factor is deterministic, isGreaterThan is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_isGreaterThan p(isGreaterThan) factor(isGreaterThan,a,b))).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.JaggedSubarrayOp`1.ArrayAverageLogarithm``3(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``2},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32}},``1)
member.summary: VMP message to array.
member.param: Incoming message from items. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except array. Because the factor is deterministic, items is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(indices) p(indices) log(sum_items p(items) factor(items,array,indices))).

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(factor(log,d)).

member.summary: VMP message to A.
member.param: Incoming message from matrixMultiply. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from B. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the A argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except A. Because the factor is deterministic, matrixMultiply is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(B) p(B) log(sum_matrixMultiply p(matrixMultiply) factor(matrixMultiply,A,B))).

member.param: Incoming message from val1. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from val2. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the val1 argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of val1 as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(val1) sum_(val2) p(val2) factor(max,val1,val2)]/p(val1).

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of val1 as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(val1) sum_(max) p(max) factor(max,val1,val2)]/p(val1).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.MultinomialOp
member.remarks: The factor is f(sample,p,n) = n!/prod_k sample[k]! prod_k p[k]^sample[k]

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.MultinomialOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Discrete})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(multinomial) p(multinomial) factor(multinomial,trialCount,probs) / sum_multinomial p(multinomial) messageTo(multinomial)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.MultinomialOp.LogAverageFactor(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's average value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(multinomial,probs) p(multinomial,probs) factor(multinomial,trialCount,probs)).

member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.returns: Average of the factor's log-value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is sum_(multinomial,probs) p(multinomial,probs) log(factor(multinomial,trialCount,probs)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.MultinomialOp.MeanLog(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet)
member.summary: Update the buffer MeanLog.
member.returns: New value of buffer MeanLog.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.MultinomialOp.AverageLogFactor(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},System.Int32,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.returns: Average of the factor's log-value across the given argument distributions.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is sum_(multinomial,probs) p(multinomial,probs) log(factor(multinomial,trialCount,probs)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.MultinomialOp.PAverageLogarithm(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},System.Int32)
member.summary: VMP message to probs.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the probs argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except probs. The formula is exp(sum_(multinomial) p(multinomial) log(factor(multinomial,trialCount,probs))).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.NonconjugateUsesEqualDefOp
member.summary: UsesEqualDef operator to combine Gaussian and nonconjugate messages.

The marginal distribution is the same as the message to uses.

member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the a argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except a. Because the factor is deterministic, or is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_or p(or) factor(or,a,b))).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianProductOp_SHG09
member.summary:
Provides outgoing messages for the following factors:
, given random arguments to the function.
member.remarks: This class allows EP to process the product factor as if running VMP, as required by Stern's algorithm. The algorithm comes from "Matchbox: Large Scale Online Bayesian Recommendations" by David Stern, Ralf Herbrich, and Thore Graepel, WWW 2009.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.GaussianProductVmpOp.AAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to a.
member.param: Incoming message from product. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from b. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the a argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except a. Because the factor is deterministic, product is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(b) p(b) log(sum_product p(product) factor(product,a,b))).

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except b. The formula is exp(sum_(a) p(a) log(factor(productExp,a,b))).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.ProductWishartOp.LogEvidenceRatio(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Wishart,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Wishart,System.Double)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(product,a) p(product,a) factor(product,a,b) / sum_product p(product) messageTo(product)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.RotateOp.AverageLogFactor(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian)
member.summary: Evidence message for VMP.
member.returns: Zero.

remarks.para: In Variational Message Passing, the evidence contribution of a deterministic factor is zero. Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for VMP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.RotateOp.XAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.WrappedGaussian)
member.summary: VMP message to x.
member.param: Incoming message from rotate. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
Incoming message from angle. Must be a proper distribution. If uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the x argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except x. Because the factor is deterministic, rotate is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(angle) p(angle) log(sum_rotate p(rotate) factor(rotate,x,y,angle))).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.RotateOp.YAverageLogarithm(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.WrappedGaussian)

member.param: Incoming message from rotate. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.

member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the y argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except y. Because the factor is deterministic, rotate is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(angle) p(angle) log(sum_rotate p(rotate) factor(rotate,x,y,angle))).

member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.
member.remarks: Here the marginal prototype for logOdds is Gamma, which allows for heavier tailed distributions. This implementation uses the Taylor series bound from Blei 06, followed by optimization using LBFGS. This approach is linear in the dimension K.

member.summary: VMP message to sample.
member.param: Incoming message from probTrue. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.

member.summary: VMP message to array.
member.param: Incoming message from items. Must be a proper distribution. If all elements are uniform, the result will be uniform.
Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except array. Because the factor is deterministic, items is integrated out before taking the logarithm. The formula is exp(sum_(indices) p(indices) log(sum_items p(items) factor(items,array,indices))).

The type of the outgoing message.

member.summary: A base class for implementations of message passing operations for string formatting factors that don't support specifying argument names.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFormatOpBase_NoArgumentNames`1.ArgumentCountToNames
member.summary: Maps the number of argument to an array of default argument names ("0", "1" and so on).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFormatOpBase_NoArgumentNames`1.GetArgumentNames(System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates an array of default argument names ("0", "1" and so on) given the number of arguments.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFormatOp_RequireEveryPlaceholder_NoArgumentNames

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFormatOp_AllowMissingPlaceholders_NoArgumentNames
member.summary: An implementation of message passing operations for the string formatting factor that does not support argument names and requires every argument placeholder to be present in a format string.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFromArrayOp
member.summary: Provides outgoing messages for , given random arguments to the function.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFromArrayOp.StrAverageConditional(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DiscreteChar})
member.summary: EP message to str.
member.returns: The outgoing EP message to the str argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of str as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(str) sum_(characters) p(characters) factor(str,characters)]/p(str).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFromArrayOp.CharactersAverageConditional``1(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.StringDistribution,System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DiscreteChar},``0)
member.summary: EP message to characters.
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of characters as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(characters) sum_(str) p(str) factor(str,characters)]/p(characters).

member.typeparam: The type of an outgoing message to chars.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFromArrayOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DiscreteChar},Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.StringDistribution)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(characters,str) p(characters,str) factor(str,characters) / sum_str p(str) messageTo(str)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFromArrayOp.LogEvidenceRatio(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DiscreteChar},System.String)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(characters) p(characters) factor(str,characters)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.StringFromArrayOp.GetCharWeighter(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DiscreteChar},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a string distribution P(s) = \prod_i P_i(s_i)^I[i != j], where P_i(c) is a given array of character distributions and j is a given position in the array.
member.returns: The created distribution.

member.summary: VMP message to sum.
member.param: Modified to contain the outgoing message.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of sum as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[sum_(array) p(array) factor(sum,array)].

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.SumVectorGaussianOp.ArrayAverageLogarithm``1(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian},``0)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.UnaryOp`1.LogEvidenceRatio``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(random,dist) p(random,dist) factor(random,dist) / sum_random p(random) messageTo(random)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.summary: EP message to random.

member.typeparam: The type of the distribution over the sampled variable.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.UnaryOp`1.RandomAverageLogarithm``1(``0)
member.summary: VMP message to random.
member.returns: The outgoing VMP message to the random argument.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is the exponential of the average log-factor value, where the average is over all arguments except random. The formula is exp(sum_(dist) p(dist) log(factor(random,dist))).

member.typeparam: The type of the distribution over the sampled variable.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.Undirected.LinearTrunc(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Implements a truncated linear difference potential which has the value of exp( - min( |a-b|* logUnitCost, maxCost) ).

member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Factors.VectorGaussianOp.LogEvidenceRatio(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.PositiveDefiniteMatrix)
member.summary: Evidence message for EP.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sample) p(sample) factor(sample,mean,precision) / sum_sample p(sample) messageTo(sample)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

remarks.para: The outgoing message is a distribution matching the moments of sample as the random arguments are varied. The formula is proj[p(sample) sum_(mean) p(mean) factor(sample,mean,precision)]/p(sample).

member.param: Incoming message from precision. Must be a proper distribution. If any element is uniform, the result will be uniform.
member.returns: Logarithm of the factor's contribution the EP model evidence.

remarks.para: The formula for the result is log(sum_(sample,mean,precision) p(sample,mean,precision) factor(sample,mean,precision) / sum_sample p(sample) messageTo(sample)). Adding up these values across all factors and variables gives the log-evidence estimate for EP.

member.remarks: There are often special case constructors or factory methods which apply when an object is in a particular state e.g. when a distribution is uniform. member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Utilities.Hash
member.summary: Utilities for implementing GetHashCode().

remarks.para: To hash an object with two fields x and y: return Hash.Combine(x.GetHashCode(), y.GetHashCode());
Algorithm: FNV hash from http://www.isthe.com/chongo/tech/comp/fnv/

Note: You should not use xor to combine hash codes, even though it is recommended by MSDN. xor is invariant to permutation, which means "abc" and "bac" and "cba" will hash to the same value (bad). Also xoring a hash value with itself produces 0, so "aab" and "b" will hash to the same value (bad).

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Utilities.Hash.Start
member.summary: The recommended start value for a combined hash value

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Utilities.Hash.Combine(System.Int32,System.Byte)
member.summary: Combines an existing hash key with a new byte value
member.param: New byte of the new hash code to be integrated
member.returns: A new hash-count that is neither order invariant nor "idempotent"

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Utilities.Hash.Combine(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Combines two int32 hash keys
member.returns: Incorporates the second hash key into the first hash key and returns the new, combined hash key

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Utilities.Hash.Combine(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Incorporates the hash key of a double into an existing hash key
member.returns: The new, combined hash key

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5
member.content: Contains the class used to represent a condensation of the automaton graph.
member.summary: Abstract base class for a weighted finite state automaton. It can be viewed as a function that maps arbitrary sequences of elements to real values.
member.typeparam: The type of a sequence.
The type of a sequence element.
The type of a distribution over sequence elements.
The type providing ways to manipulate sequences.
The type of a concrete automaton class.
member.content: Contains classes and methods for automata simplification.
Contains the class used to represent the epsilon closure of a state of an automaton.
Extracts groups from a loop-free automaton.
Contains classes and methods for automata simplification.
Contains the class used to represent the condensation of an automaton graph.
Contains the class used to represent a transition in an automaton.#

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Builder.TransitionIterator
member.summary: Helper struct for iterating over currently constructed list of transitions for state. Unlike standard enumerator pattern through this iterator elements can be changed and removed.
member.remarks: Implemented as a value type to minimize amount of GC.

Implementation does not follow common due to three reasons. - Items are mutable through this iterator (unlike enumerators) - Implementation-wise initializing iterator in "valid" state is easier than in the one which requires MoveNext() call - Iterator with this interface can conveniently be used in a for-loop unlike traditional enumerators which will require 3 lines in a while-loop

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Condensation.FindStronglyConnectedComponents
member.summary: Implements Tarjan's algorithm for finding the strongly connected components of the automaton graph.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Condensation.ComputeWeightsToEnd
member.summary: For each state of the component, computes the total weight of all paths starting at that state. Ending weights are taken into account.
member.remarks: The weights are computed using dynamic programming, going up from leafs to the root.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Condensation.ComputeWeightsFromRoot
member.summary: For each state of the component, computes the total weight of all paths starting at the root and ending at that state. Ending weights are not taken into account.
member.remarks: The weights are computed using dynamic programming, going down from the root to leafs.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Repeat(`4,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Creates an automaton g(s) = sum_k v(k) sum_{t1 t2 ... tk = s} f(t1)f(t2)...f(tk), where f(t) is the given automaton, and v(k) is a weight function given as a vector.
member.returns: The created automaton.
member.remarks: The result is a weighted sum of Cauchy products of the given automaton with itself, each product having a different number of factors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Repeat(`4,System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Creates an automaton g(s) = sum_{k=Kmin}^{Kmax} sum_{t1 t2 ... tk = s} f(t1)f(t2)...f(tk), where f(t) is the given automaton, and Kmin and Kmax are the minimum and the maximum number of factors in a sum term.
member.param: The minimum number of factors in a sum term. Defaults to 1.
An optional maximum number of factors in a sum term.
member.returns: The created automaton.
member.remarks: The result is the sum of Cauchy products of the given automaton with itself, each product having a different number of factors.

member.returns: if the automaton is a canonic representation of zero, otherwise.
member.remarks: The time complexity of this function is O(1), so it can be used to treat zero specially in performance-critical code. All the operations on automata resulting in zero produce the canonic representation.

member.summary: Represents

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Determinization.WeightedState.Index
member.summary: Index of the state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Determinization.WeightedState.WeightHighBits
member.summary: High bits of the state weight. Only these bits are used when comparing weighted states for equality or when calculating hash code.
member.remarks: Using high bits for hash code allows to have "fuzzy" matching of WeightedStateSets. Sometimes there's more than one way to get to the same weighted state set in automaton, but due to using floating point numbers calculated weights are slightly off. Using only high 32 bits for comparison means that 20 bits of mantissa are used. Which means that difference between weights (in log space) is no more than ~~ 10e-6 which is a sufficiently good precision for all practical purposes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Simplification.#ctor(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton{`0,`1,`2,`3,`4}.Builder,System.Nullable{System.Double})
member.summary: Initializes new instance of class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Simplification.SimplifyIfNeeded
member.summary: Attempts to simplify the automaton using if the number of states exceeds .

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Simplification.Simplify
member.summary: Attempts to simplify the structure of the automaton, reducing the number of states and transitions.
member.remarks:
Only generalized tree part of automaton is simplified. Generalized tree is a tree with self-loops allowed. Any non-trivial loops (consisting of more than 1 state) are left untouched.
The simplification procedure works as follows: * If a pair of states has more than one transition between them, the transitions get merged. * A part of the automaton that is a tree is found. For example in this automaton: a--->b--->c--->d---\ v ^ | e--->f--->g \--/ | v h--->i--->j-->k ^ | \--/ Nodes "a" to "h" form the tree. Nodes "i" to "k" are not part of the tree. Note 1: h has child nodes which form loop (i, j) but is still considered a part of tree. Because path leading to it from root has no loops. Note 2: d is also considered to be a part of tree. Self-loops are allowed. * After that, states in the tree part of automaton are recursively merged if they are compatible. Two states are considered compatible if path from root to them has exactly same element distributions and groups on transitions, and they have compatible self-loops. Weights in transitions from root can be different - weights will be adjusted as necessary. For example if in previous automaton transitions (a-b) and (a-e) have the same element distribution then result will look like this:
a--->b--->c--->d---\ | \ ^ | e | f--->g \--/ | v h--->i--->j-->k ^ | \--/ * If pruneStatesWithLogEndWeightLessThan is not null then log normalizer and graph condensation computed. All states which do not have high enough end probability are deleted

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Simplification.MergeParallelTransitions
member.summary: Merges outgoing transitions with the same destination state.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.Automaton`5.Simplification.RemoveDeadStates
member.summary: Optimizes the automaton by removing all states which can't reach end states.
member.remarks: This function looks a lot like . But unfortunately operates on a different graph representation.

member.remarks: Whenever a transition is being cloned, the element distribution is not being cloned, so the two copies share the same element distribution instance. Therefore, a manual change to an element distribution can affect multiple functions and should be avoided.

members.member: Note the order of fields. This struct is densely packed and should take only 24 bytes to store all its fields in case of StringAutomaton.Transition. Think wisely before you decide to reorder fields or change their types.

member.summary: A base class for distributions over pairs of elements used to specify transducers.
member.typeparam: The type of a first element of a pair.
The type of a distribution over .
The type of a second element of a pair.
The type of a distribution over .
The type of a concrete pair distribution class.

remarks.p: Default interface implementations available in this class assume that the distribution is fully factorized: P(x, y) = P(x) P(y), where P(x) is given by and P(y) is given by second. Implementations of another kinds of pair distributions must override the interface implementation to ensure the correct behavior.

One of the element distributions can be to encode an epsilon input or an epsilon output in a transducer. Both distributions cannot be null at the same time: epsilon transition in transducers are specified by setting pair distributions to .

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.RegexpTreeNode`1.SmallStringKeyDictionary`1
member.summary: A custom dictionary for mapping strings to values. A key lookup takes linear time.
member.remarks: Can be faster than when the number of strings is small, and the strings are long. There are two reasons for that. First, the linear search procedure used has almost no overhead. Second, needs to look through every string to compute its hash code, while the linear search procedure usually looks only at a couple characters in every string, so it can work with long strings without much performance loss.
member.typeparam: The type of a value.

member.summary: Creates a transducer T'(a, b) = sum_{k=Kmin}^{Kmax} sum_{a1 a2 ... ak = a} sum_{b1 b2 ... bk = b} T(a1, b1)T(a2, b2)...T(ak, bk), where T(a, b) is a given transducer, and Kmin and Kmax are the minimum and the maximum number of factors in a sum term.
member.param: The minimum number of factors in a sum term. Defaults to 1.
An optional maximum number of factors in a sum term.
member.returns: The created transducer.
member.remarks: The result is the sum of Cauchy products of the given transducer with itself, each product having a different number of factors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.TransducerBase`12.Append(`11)
member.summary: Creates a transducer T'(a, b) = sum_{a1 a2 = a, b1 b2 = b} T(a1, b1) U(a2, b2), where T(a1, b1) is the current transducer and U(a2, b2) is a given transducer. The resulting transducer is also known as the Cauchy product of two transducers.
member.returns: The created transducer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.TransducerBase`12.AppendInPlace(`11,System.Int32)
member.summary: Replaces the current transducer with a transducer T'(a, b) = sum_{a1 a2 = a, b1 b2 = b} T(a1, b1) U(a2, b2), where T(a1, b1) is the current transducer and U(a2, b2) is a given transducer. The resulting transducer is also known as the Cauchy product of two transducers.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.TransducerBase`12.ProjectSource(`4)
member.summary: Computes g(b) = sum_a f(a) T(a, b), where T(a, b) is the current transducer and f(a) is a given automaton.
member.returns: The projection.
member.remarks: The code of this method has a lot in common with the code of Automaton.SetToProduct. Unfortunately, it's not clear how to avoid the duplication in the current design.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Automata.TransducerBase`12.ProjectSource(`0)
member.summary: Computes g(b) = f(A) T(A, b), where T(a, b) is the current transducer and A is a given sequence.
member.returns: The projection.
member.remarks: Using this method is more efficient than applying to the automaton representation of a projected sequence.
The code of this method has a lot in common with the code of Automaton.SetToProduct. Unfortunately, it's not clear how to avoid the duplication in the current design.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli
member.summary: Represents a distribution on a binary variable.
member.remarks:
The most common way to use the distribution is to get and set its ProbTrue property.
The distribution is represented by a single number, the log odds: log p(x=true)/p(x=false). If this is 0, then the distribution is uniform. If this is infinity, then the distribution is a point mass on x=true. If this is -infinity, then the distribution is a point mass on x=false. In terms of the log odds, p(x=true) = 1/(1+exp(-logOdds)).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli.LogitProbEqual(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logical AreEqual function in the log-odds domain.
member.param: The log-odds of variable A, which can be any real number from -Inf to Inf.
The log-odds of variable B, which can be any real number from -Inf to Inf.
member.returns: The log-odds that A == B.
member.remarks: The logical LogitProbEqual function is defined as p1 EQ p2 = p1*p2 + (1-p1)*(1-p2). It is the same as the complement of XOR: !(p1 XOR p2). In the log-odds domain, this is: LogOdds(Logistic(x) EQ Logistic(y)) = log (1+exp(-x-y))/(exp(-x)+exp(-y)). To compute this reliably when x>0 and y>0, factor out min(x,y). For other cases, use the identity AE(-x,-y) = AE(x,y) and AE(-x,y) = AE(x,-y) = -AE(x,y). Note the result is 0 if x=0 or y=0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli.LogProbEqual(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the log-probability that A==B where p(A)=Logistic(x), p(B)=Logistic(y).
member.param: The log-odds of variable A, which can be any real number from -Inf to Inf.
The log-odds of variable B, which can be any real number from -Inf to Inf.
member.returns: The log-probability that A==B.
member.remarks: The result is Math.Log(0.5) if x=0 or y=0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli.Or(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logical OR function in the log-odds domain.
member.returns: The log odds of (p1 OR p2), where p1 = Logistic(x) and p2 = Logistic(y)
member.remarks: The logical OR function is defined as p1 OR p2 = 1 - (1-p1)*(1-p2) = p1 + p2 - p1*p2. In the log-odds domain, this is: LogOdds(Logistic(x) OR Logistic(y)) = log(exp(x) + exp(y) + exp(x+y)). To compute this reliably, factor out max(x,y,x+y).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Bernoulli.Gate(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the Bernoulli gating function in the log-odds domain.
member.remarks: The Bernoulli gating function is x if gate = -infinity and 0 if gate = infinity. It is one of the messages sent by a logical OR factor. In the log-odds domain, this is: log (1 + exp(-gate))/(1 + exp(-gate-x))

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Beta
member.summary: A Beta distribution over the interval [0,1].

remarks.para: The Beta is often used as a distribution on probability values. The formula for the distribution is p(x) = (Gamma(trueCount+falseCount)/Gamma(trueCount)/Gamma(falseCount)) x^{trueCount-1} (1-x)^(falseCount-1) subject to the constraint 0 <= x <= 1.

If trueCount = falseCount = 1, the distribution is uniform. If falseCount = infinity, the distribution is redefined to be a point mass on trueCount. When trueCount <= 0 or falseCount <= 0, the distribution is improper. In this case, the density is redefined to not include the Gamma terms, i.e. there is no normalizer.

member.summary: Whether the distribution is proper or not. It is improper when trueCount <= 0 or falseCount <= 0 in which case it cannot be normalised
member.returns: true if proper, false otherwise

member.summary: Creates a Beta distribution with the given parameters.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Beta.FromMeanLogs(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a Beta distribution with the given E[log(p)] and E[log(1-p)].
member.returns: A new Beta distribution.
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Beta distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. So we want to maximize (a-1)eLogP + (b-1)eLogOneMinusP + Gamma(a+b) - Gamma(a) - Gamma(b) with respect to a, b where a=trueCount, b=falseCount. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Binomial
member.summary: Binomial distribution over the integers [0,n]
member.remarks: The formula for the distribution is p(x) = n!/(n-x)!/x! p^x (1-p)^(n-x). In this implementation, we use a generalization that includes two extra shape parameters (a,b) The formula for the generalized distribution is p(x) =propto 1/x!^a 1/(n-x)!^b exp(x*logOdds). With this extension, we can represent a uniform distribution via (logOdds=0,a=0,b=0) and a point mass via logOdds=+/-infinity or a=infinity or b=infinity. This family is closed under multiplication, while the standard Binomial is not.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet
member.summary: A Dirichlet distribution on probability vectors.

remarks.para: The Dirichlet is a distribution on probability vectors. The formula for the distribution is p(x) = (Gamma(a)/prod_i Gamma(b_i)) prod_i x_i^{b_i-1} subject to the constraints x_i >= 0 and sum_i x_i = 1. The parameter a is the "total pseudo-count" and is shorthand for sum_i b_i. The vector b contains the pseudo-counts for each case i. The vector b can be sparse or dense; in many cases it is useful to give it a specification of .

The distribution is represented by the pair (TotalCount, PseudoCount). If TotalCount is infinity, the distribution is a point mass. The Point property gives the mean. Otherwise TotalCount is always equal to PseudoCount.Sum(). If distribution is uniform when all PseudoCounts = 1. If any PseudoCount <= 0, the distribution is improper. In this case, the density is redefined to not include the Gamma terms, i.e. there is no normalizer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet.TotalCount
member.summary: Gets the total count. If infinite, the distribution is a point mass. Otherwise, this is the sum of pseudo-counts

member.summary: Vector of pseudo-counts

member.returns: The variance

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet.SetMeanAndMeanSquare(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Sets the mean, and sets the precision to best match the given mean-squares.
member.param: Desired mean in each dimension. Must be in [0,1] and sum to 1.
Desired meanSquare in each dimension. Must be in [0,1].
member.remarks: The resulting distribution will have the given mean but will only approximately match the meanSquare, since the Dirichlet does not have enough parameters. The moment matching formula comes from: "Expectation-Propagation for the Generative Aspect Model", Thomas Minka and John Lafferty, Proceedings of the 18th Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, pp. 352-359, 2002 http://research.microsoft.com/~minka/papers/aspect/

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet.SetMeanAndVariance(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Sets the mean, and sets the precision to best match the given variances.
member.param: Desired mean in each dimension. Must be in [0,1] and sum to 1.
Desired variance in each dimension. Must be non-negative.
member.remarks: The resulting distribution will have the given mean but will only approximately match the variance, since the Dirichlet does not have enough parameters. The moment matching formula comes from: "Expectation-Propagation for the Generative Aspect Model", Thomas Minka and John Lafferty, Proceedings of the 18th Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, pp. 352-359, 2002 http://research.microsoft.com/~minka/papers/aspect/

member.summary: Sets the mean and precision to best match the given derivatives at a point.
member.param: Desired derivative of log-density at x
Desired second derivative of log-density at x
If true and both derivatives cannot be matched by a distribution with counts at least 1, match only the first.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Dirichlet.FromMeanLog(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.Vector)
member.summary: Create a Dirichlet distribution with the given expected logarithms.
member.param: Desired expectation E[log(pk)] for each k.
member.returns: A new Dirichlet where GetMeanLog == meanLog
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Dirichlet distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization. Uses the Newton algorithm described in "Estimating a Dirichlet distribution" by T. Minka, 2000.

member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Dirichlet distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other setters since it involves nonlinear optimization. Uses the Newton algorithm described in "Estimating a Dirichlet distribution" by T. Minka, 2000.

member.summary: Represents a distribution over characters.

member.summary: Ranges of only lowercase characters, excluding the mixed range.

member.summary: Ranges of only uppercase characters, excluding the mixed range

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DiscreteChar.MixedCaseCharacterRanges
member.summary: Ranges of mixed upper and lower case characters, which are merged for computational efficiency reasons.
member.remarks:
In some Unicode ranges, upper and lower characters alternate which makes it very expensive to represent just lower or just upper characters using ranges. Instead, we use a loose approximation and allow characters in such ranges to be considered either lower or upper case.
This approximation means that upper and lower case character ranges are no longer mutually exclusive.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.IDistribution`1
member.summary: Distribution interface
member.typeparam: The type of objects in the domain, e.g. Vector or Matrix.

remarks.para: T should generally have value semantics, i.e. it should override Equals to use value equality. Otherwise it implies a Distribution over references.
In addition to this interface, Distributions should override Equals to use value equality. A typical implementation of Equals is: MaxDiff(that) == 0.0

To be generally used by message-passing algorithms, a distribution should also implement the following interfaces: SettableTo, SettableToProduct, SettableToRatio, SettableToPower, SettableToWeightedSum, CanGetLogAverageOf, CanGetAverageLog

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.HasPoint`1
member.summary: Whether the distribution supports being a point mass

member.name: P:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.HasPoint`1.Point
member.summary: Access the location of a point mass.

remarks.para: If the distribution parameters do not represent a point mass, getting this property returns an undefined value (if T is a ValueType) or a storage area with undefined contents (if T is a reference type). It should not throw an exception. Setting Point will change the distribution into a point mass, overriding any other property settings. Note: Point = Point does have an effect!
If T is a reference type, then the result is volatile. Its contents expire upon invoking any subsequent distribution method.
Point is a property because it is expected that each distribution would have a corresponding data field. Accessing the Point should take constant time.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Distribution.GetLogAverageOf``2(``0[],``1[])
member.summary: The log-probability that two distributions would draw the same sample.
member.typeparam: Element type of this distribution array
Element type of that distribution array
member.param: The distribution to take the logarithm of.
member.remarks: This can be considered a type of inner product between distributions. Another name might be "LogAverage" to go with "GetAverageLog". For an array, this specializes to: sum_i Math.Log(sum_x this[i].Evaluate(x)*that[i].Evaluate(x)) = sum_i this[i].GetLogAverageOf(that[i])

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DistributionRefArray`2.GetLogAverageOf(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DistributionRefArray{`0,`1})
member.summary: The log-probability that two distributions would draw the same sample.
member.remarks: This can be considered a type of inner product between distributions. Another name might be "LogAverage" to go with "GetAverageLog". For a DistributionArray, this specializes to: sum_i Math.Log(sum_x this[i].Evaluate(x)*that[i].Evaluate(x)) = sum_i this[i].GetLogAverageOf(that[i])

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DistributionRefArray`2.GetLogAverageOfPower(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DistributionRefArray{`0,`1},System.Double)
member.summary: Get the integral of this distribution times another distribution raised to a power.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DistributionRefArray`2.GetAverageLog(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.DistributionRefArray{`0,`1})
member.summary: The expected logarithm of that distribution under this distribution.
member.param: The distribution to take the logarithm of.
member.remarks: This is also known as the cross entropy. For a DistributionArray, this specializes to: sum_i sum_x this[i].Evaluate(x)*Math.Log(that[i].Evaluate(x)) = sum_i this[i].GetAverageLog(that[i])

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma
member.summary: A Gamma distribution on positive reals.

remarks.para: The distribution is p(x) = x^(a-1)*exp(-x*b)*b^a/Gamma(a). In this code, the a parameter is called the "Shape" and the b parameter is called the "Rate". The distribution is sometimes also parameterized by (shape,scale) where scale = 1/rate. The mean of the distribution is shape/rate and the variance is shape/rate^2.

Special cases: When the shape is 1 and rate is 0, the distribution is uniform. When the shape is infinity, the distribution is a point mass and the density is delta(x-Point) where the Point property gives the mean. When a <= 0 or b <= 0 the b^a/Gamma(a) term is dropped.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gamma.FromMeanAndMeanLog(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a Gamma distribution with the given mean and mean logarithm.
member.returns: A new Gamma distribution.
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Gamma distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization. The algorithm is a generalized Newton iteration, described in "Estimating a Gamma distribution" by T. Minka, 2002.

member.remarks: This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization. The algorithm is a generalized Newton iteration, described in "Estimating a Gamma distribution" by T. Minka, 2002.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.GammaPower
member.summary: The distribution of a Gamma variable raised to a power. The Weibull distribution is a special case.

remarks.para: The Gamma-power distribution is defined as the distribution of a Gamma(a,b) variable raised to the power c. Thus it has three parameters (a,b,c) and probability density function p(x) = x^(a/c-1)*exp(-b*x^(1/c))*b^a/Gamma(a)/abs(c). In this implementation, the a parameter is called the "Shape", the b parameter is called the "Rate", and the c parameter is called the "Power". The power can be any real number, positive or negative. The distribution is sometimes also parameterized by (shape,scale,power) where scale = 1/rate.

Special cases: When the power is 1 it reduces to a Gamma distribution. When the shape is 1 it reduces to a Weibull distribution. When the shape equals the power and rate is 0, the distribution is uniform. When the shape is infinity, the distribution is a point mass and the density is delta(x-Point) where the Point property gives the mean. When the power is zero, the distribution is a point mass at one. When a <= 0 or b <= 0 the b^a/Gamma(a)/abs(c) term is dropped.

member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Gamma distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization. The algorithm is a generalized Newton iteration, described in "Estimating a Gamma distribution" by T. Minka, 2002.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian
member.summary: Represents a one-dimensional Gaussian distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution is represented by two parameters: MeanTimesPrecision and Precision. Precision is the inverse of the variance, so a Gaussian with mean m and variance v is represented as Precision = 1/v, MeanTimesPrecision = m/v.

Some special cases: If the Precision is zero, then the distribution is uniform. If the Precision is infinite, then the distribution is a point mass. The Point property gives the location of the point mass.

The formula for the distribution is: N(x;m,v) = 1/sqrt(2*pi*v) * exp(-(x-m)^2/(2v)). When v=0, this reduces to delta(x-m). When v=infinity, the density is redefined to be 1. When v < 0, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5*x^2*(1/v) + x*(m/v)), i.e. we drop the terms exp(-m^2/(2v))/sqrt(2*pi*v).

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian.GetLogProb(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates the log of one-dimensional Gaussian density.
member.param: Any real number. May be zero or negative.
member.remarks: N(x;m,v) = 1/sqrt(2*pi*v) * exp(-(x-m)^2/(2v)). When v=0, this reduces to delta(x-m). When v=infinity, the density is redefined to be 1. When v < 0, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5*x^2*(1/v) + x*(m/v)), i.e. we drop the terms exp(-m^2/(2v))/sqrt(2*pi*v).

member.remarks: This is also known as the cross entropy.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian.GetLogAverageOf(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Gaussian)
member.summary: Gets the integral of the product of two Gaussians.
member.remarks: this = N(x;m1,v1). that = N(x;m2,v2). int_(-infinity)^(infinity) N(x;m1,v1) N(x;m2,v2) dx = N(m1; m2, v1+v2). When improper, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5*x^2*(1/v) + x*(m/v)), i.e. we drop the terms exp(-m^2/(2v))/sqrt(2*pi*v).
member.returns: log(N(m1;m2,v1+v2)).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SparseGP
member.summary: A Gaussian Process distribution over functions, represented by a GP prior times a set of regression likelihoods on basis points.

remarks.para: This distribution family comes from the paper "Sparse-posterior Gaussian Processes for general likelihoods" by Qi et al (2010), http://event.cwi.nl/uai2010/papers/UAI2010_0283.pdf

The state of the distribution is represented by (FixedParameters, IncludePrior, InducingDist, pointFunc). The GP prior and basis point locations are stored in FixedParameters. The regression likelihoods are stored as a single VectorGaussian called InducingDist. IncludePrior=false does not include the prior in the distribution (i.e. the distribution is degenerate). If pointFunc != null, the distribution is a point mass. If InducingDist is uniform and IncludePrior is false, the distribution is uniform. The GP prior is assumed to be non-uniform.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.GenericDiscreteBase`2
member.summary: A generic base class for discrete distributions over a type T.
member.remarks:
This class makes it straightforward to implement discrete distributions over types other than int. It is only necessary to make a subclass of this abstract class, add a constructor and implement two methods to convert the desired type T to and from an integer.
Internally, this class wraps a Discrete distribution and uses it to provide all functionality.
member.typeparam: The domain type of this distribution
The type of the subclass (allows factory methods return the correct type)

member.summary: Gets a Vector of size this.Dimension.

member.remarks: This function is intended to be used with SetProbs, to avoid allocating a new Vector. The return value should not be interpreted as a probs vector, but only a workspace filled with unknown data that can be overwritten. member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Pareto
member.summary: A Pareto distribution over the real numbers from lowerBound to infinity.
member.remarks: The distribution has two parameters (shape, lowerBound) which must be positive for the distribution to be proper. Its density function is p(x) = s L^s / x^(s+1) for x >= L. If shape = -1, the distribution is uniform. If shape = infinity, the distribution is a point mass on the lowerBound.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Poisson
member.summary: A Poisson distribution over the integers [0,infinity).

remarks.para: The Poisson is often used as a distribution on counts. The formula for the distribution is p(x) = rate^x exp(-rate) / x! where rate is the rate parameter. This implementation uses a generalization called the Conway-Maxwell Poisson or "Com-Poisson", which has an extra precision parameter nu. The formula for the distribution is p(x) =propto rate^x / x!^nu. The Com-Poisson can represent a uniform distribution via (rate=1,nu=0) and a point mass via rate=0 or nu=infinity. This family is closed under multiplication, while the standard Poisson is not.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Poisson.Rate
member.summary: The rate parameter of the COM-Poisson distribution, always >= 0.
member.remarks: The natural parameter of the distribution is log(rate). However, since rate remains >= 0 under multiplication, there is no harm in using rate as the parameter.

member.summary: The precision parameter of the COM-Poisson distribution

member.remarks: The formula for the distribution is p(x) = rate^x exp(-rate) / x! when nu=1. In the general case, it is p(x) =propto rate^x / x!^nu. If the distribution is improper, the normalizer is omitted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.QuantileEstimator
member.summary: Subsamples data to provide accurate estimation of quantiles.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.QuantileEstimator.buffers
member.summary: Stores a subset of added items, each with a different weight. All items in the same buffer have the same weight. Items in the lowest buffer have weight 2^lowestBufferHeight. Items in the next buffer have twice as much weight, and so on. To allow adding without overflow, the highest buffer must satisfy the following invariant: countInBuffer[bufferIndex] <= buffers[bufferIndex].Length/2 where bufferIndex = (lowestBufferIndex-1)

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.QuantileEstimator.lowestBufferHeight
member.summary: Always at least 0 and at most 30.

member.name: F:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.QuantileEstimator.InterpolationType
member.summary: 0 = point mass on each data point (i/n) 1 = interpolate (i/n + (i+1)/n)/2 = (i+0.5)/n 2 = interpolate i/(n-1)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.QuantileEstimator.#ctor(System.Double)

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.Repeat(`5,System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Int32})

summary.para: Creates a distribution by applying to the weight function of a given distribution, which is additionally scaled by the inverse of with itself. So, if the given distribution is partial uniform, the result will be partial uniform over the repetitions of sequences covered by the distribution.
If is set to , there will be no upper bound on the length, and the resulting distribution will thus be improper.

member.param: The minimum number of repetitions. Defaults to 1.
The maximum number of repetitions, or for no upper bound. Defaults to .
member.returns: The created distribution.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.Append(`1,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a distribution over concatenations of sequences from the current distribution and a given element.
member.param: The group for the appended element.
member.remarks:
The result is equivalent to the distribution produced by the following sampling procedure:
Sample a random sequence from the current distribution.
Append the given element to the sampled sequence and output the result.
member.returns: The distribution over the concatenations of sequences and the element.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.Append(`2,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a distribution over concatenations of sequences from the current distribution and elements from a given distribution.
member.param: The distribution to generate the elements from.
The group for the appended element.
member.remarks:
The result is equivalent to the distribution produced by the following sampling procedure:
Sample a random sequence from the current distribution.
2) Sample a random element from .
3) Append the sampled element to the sampled sequence and output the result.
member.returns: The distribution over the concatenations of sequences and elements.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.Append(`0,System.Int32)

member.remarks:

member.returns: The distribution over the concatenations of sequences.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.SetWorkspace(`4,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Replaces the workspace (weight function) of the current distribution with a given one.
member.param: The workspace to replace the current one with.
Whether to normalize the structure of the distribution
member.remarks: If the given workspace represents a point mass, the distribution would be converted to a point mass and the workspace would be set to . Any modifications of the workspace will put the distribution into an undefined state.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.GetWorkspaceOrPoint
member.summary: Returns the underlying weight function, or, if the distribution is a point mass, a functional representation of the corresponding point. Any modifications of the returned function will put the distribution into an undefined state.
member.remarks: The returned weight function might differ from the probability function by an arbitrary scale factor. To ensure that the workspace is normalized, use .
member.returns: The underlying weight function or a functional representation of the point.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.GetNormalizedWorkspaceOrPoint
member.summary: Returns the underlying weight function, or, if the distribution is a point mass, a functional representation of the corresponding point. Any modifications of the returned function will put the distribution into an undefined state.
member.remarks: The returned weight function is guaranteed to be normalized. If you don't care about an arbitrary scale factor, consider using which has less overhead.
member.returns: The underlying weight function or a functional representation of the point.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SequenceDistribution`6.EnumerateComponents
member.summary: Enumerates components of this distribution.
member.remarks:
Any sequence distribution can be represented as a mixture of 'simple' sequence distributions where each element is independent. This method enumerates through the components of this distribution treated as such a mixture. Each component is returned as a list of the independent element distributions for each element.
For some distributions, the number of components may be very large.
member.returns: For each component, the list of element distributions and the log mixture weight for that component.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.SparseDistributionList`3
member.summary: Abstract base class for a homogeneous sparse list of distributions. The class supports an approximation tolerance which allows elements close to the common value to be automatically reset to the common value. The list implements the interfaces which allow these distributions to participate in message passing.
member.typeparam: The distribution type for the elements of the sparse list.
The domain type for the distribution elements.
The type of a specialized class derived from this class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.TruncatedGamma
member.summary: A distribution over real numbers between an upper and lower bound. If LowerBound=0 and UpperBound=Inf, it reduces to an ordinary Gamma distribution.
member.remarks: The distribution is parameterized by a Gamma and two real numbers (LowerBound, UpperBound). Between the bounds, the density is proportional to the Gamma. Outside of the bounds, the density is zero.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.UnnormalizedDiscrete.GetWorkspace
member.summary: Gets a Vector of size this.Dimension.
member.returns: A pointer to the internal log prob Vector of the object.
member.remarks: This function is intended to be used with SetLogProbs, to avoid allocating a new Vector. The return value should not be interpreted as a probs vector, but only a workspace filled with unknown data that can be overwritten. Until SetLogProbs is called, the distribution object is invalid once this workspace is modified.

member.remarks: Instead of allocating your own Vector to pass to SetProbs, you can call , fill in the resulting Vector, and then pass it to SetProbs.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.VectorGaussian
member.summary: Represents a multivariate Gaussian distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution is parameterized by MeanTimesPrecision and Precision. Precision is the inverse of the variance, so a Gaussian with mean m and variance v is represented as Precision = inv(v), MeanTimesPrecision = inv(v)*m.

Some special cases: If the precision is zero, then the distribution is uniform. If the precision is infinite along the diagonal, then the distribution is a point mass. The Point property gives the location of the point mass. If precision[i,i] is infinite, then the distribution is a point mass along dimension i. Point[i] gives the mean. The rest of the row and column of precision must be zero.

The formula for the distribution is: N(x;m,v) = |2*pi*v|^(-d/2) * exp(-0.5 (x-m)' inv(v) (x-m)). When v=0, this reduces to delta(x-m). When v=infinity, the density is redefined to be 1. When inv(v) is singular, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5 x' inv(v) x + x' inv(v) m), i.e. we drop the terms |2*pi*v|^(-d/2) * exp(-0.5 m' inv(v) m).

When v is singular, the density is redefined to be exp(-0.5 (x-m)' inv(v) (x-m)), i.e. we drop the terms |2*pi*v|^(-d/2).

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Wishart
member.summary: A Wishart distribution on positive definite matrices.

remarks.para: In the matrix case, the distribution is p(X) = |X|^(a-(d+1)/2)*exp(-tr(X*B))*|B|^a/Gamma_d(a). In this code, the a parameter is called the "Shape" and the B parameter is called the "Rate". The distribution is uniform when B=0 and a=(d+1)/2. The mean of the distribution is a/B and the diagonal variance is var(X_ii) = a*C_ii^2 where C=inv(B). The non-diagonal variances are var(X_ij) = a*0.5*(C_ij^2 + C_ii*C_jj) where C=inv(B).
The distribution is represented by a double for a and a PositiveDefiniteMatrix for B.

member.remarks: The distribution is p(X) = |X|^(a-(d+1)/2)*exp(-tr(X*B))*|B|^a/Gamma_d(a). When a <= (d-1)/2 the Gamma_d(a) term is dropped. When B <= 0 the |B|^a term is dropped. Thus if shape = (d+1)/2 and rate = 0 the density is 1.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Wishart.FromMeanAndMeanLogDeterminant(Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Math.PositiveDefiniteMatrix,System.Double,Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Wishart)
member.summary: Constructs a Wishart distribution with the given mean and mean log determinant.
member.returns: A new Wishart distribution.
member.remarks: This function is equivalent to maximum-likelihood estimation of a Wishart distribution from data given by sufficient statistics. This function is significantly slower than the other constructors since it involves nonlinear optimization. The algorithm is a generalized Newton iteration, described in "Estimating a Gamma distribution" by T. Minka, 2002.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.Wishart.ToString
member.summary: ToString override
member.returns: String representation of the instance

members.member:
Estimates a Wishart distribution from samples.
The distribution is estimated via moment matching (not maximum-likelihood). E[X] = (a+(d+1)/2)/B var(X_ii) = (a+(d+1)/2)*diag(inv(B))^2 because X_ii ~ Gamma(a+(d+1)/2, 1/diag(inv(B))). Therefore: a = E[X_ii]^2/var(X_ii) - (d+1)/2 B = (a+(d+1)/2)/E[X]
In the one-dimensional case, E[log(x)] = -log(b) + digamma(a+1) =approx -log(b) + log(a+1) - 1/2/(a+1) = log(E[x]) - 1/2/(a+1) In the Wishart case, E[logdet(X)] = -logdet(B) + sum_{i=0..d-1} digamma(a + (d+1-i)/2) =approx -logdet(B) + d*digamma(a+(d+1)/2) =approx -logdet(B) + d*log(a+(d+1)/2) - d/2/(a+(d+1)/2) = log(E[X}) - d/2/(a+(d+1)/2)

member.name: T:Microsoft.ML.Probabilistic.Distributions.WrappedGaussian
member.summary: A Gaussian distribution on a periodic domain, such as angles between 0 and 2*pi.
member.remarks: The distribution is represented by a unwrapped Gaussian and a period length L. To get the wrapped density, the unwrapped density is summed over all shifts by L, i.e. p(x) = sum_k N(x + Lk; m, v) over all integers k The wrapped density is automatically normalized over the range [0,L) because it simply moves the probability mass that was previously distributed over the real line to all lie in the interval [0,L).
